contents: Proponents of cursive writing argue that it is not yet obsolete. Grade school, high school, and even college still require handwritten work in the classroom, and although handwriting can include printing as well as cursive, it is important for students to be able to read documents in cursive. Primary source documents in social studies are often in cursive writing. In addition, proponents point to studies that show educational benefits of teaching handwriting skills. Handwriting (including cursive and printing) assists in cognitive and motor skills, literacy, brain development, memory, and written expression.
